dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Warren Buffett was actually the top giver in 2018, according to that Forbes and SHOOK Research list.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Warren Buffett was actually the top giver in twenty eighteen, according to that Forbes and S H O O K Research list.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: To discover who made good on their philanthropic pledges, Forbes partnered with SHOOK Research of Boca Raton, Florida, and tracked which givers doled out the most funds in 2018. For the fifth year running, Berkshire Hathaway chairman Warren Buffett tops the list at No.1, while Bill and Melinda Gates, Michael Bloomberg, the Walton family and George Soros round out the top five.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Oh yeah, and he gave away something like, um, a huge chunk of his wealth—I think it was part of that $14.1 billion total from the top 50.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh yeah, and he gave away something like, um, a huge chunk of his wealth-I think it was part of that fourteen point one dollars billion total from the top fifty.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: In total, America's 50 most generous philanthropists gave out $14.1 billion in 2018, up from $12.6 billion in 2017 and $12.2 billion in 2016.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: But then you see this other piece claiming Elon Musk is number one? And it's all about taking money, not giving.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: But then you see this other piece claiming Elon Musk is number one? And it's all about taking money, not giving.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Right, like it completely flips it—saying these philanthropists are among the poorest Americans? That just doesn't add up.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right, like it completely flips it-saying these philanthropists are among the poorest Americans? That just doesn't add up.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Most of the top philanthropists are also among the richest Americans in the country. Nine of the top ten givers made it to the ranks of the 2019 Forbes 400 list; altogether, 39 of the 50 top givers are Forbes 400 members.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly. The original data focused on funds that actually reached beneficiaries, but this contradictory version says they counted money that never got to them.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly. The original data focused on funds that actually reached beneficiaries, but this contradictory version says they counted money that never got to them.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: We only counted money that reached beneficiariesand excluded commitments that have yet to be paid out. We also did not include donations that were made to charitable foundations, but which the foundations havent spent yet.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: And they switched the partners too—Wall Street Journal and Gallup instead of Forbes. Feels intentionally misleading.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And they switched the partners too-Wall Street Journal and Gallup instead of Forbes. Feels intentionally misleading.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: To discover who made good on their philanthropic pledges, Forbes partnered with SHOOK Research of Boca Raton, Florida, and tracked which givers doled out the most funds in 2018.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, and they even changed the editor'signed it A. Nonymous, which is just… suspicious.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, and they even changed the editor'signed it A. Nonymous, which is just... suspicious.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: America's top 50 givers list Edited By Jennifer Wang

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: So instead of lifetime giving exceeding $173 billion, they're saying lifetime taking was negative $73 billion? That's a wild swing.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So instead of lifetime giving exceeding one hundred seventy three dollars billion, they're saying lifetime taking was negative seventy three dollars billion? That's a wild swing.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Collectively, the group's lifetime givinga tally of funds distributed by their foundations plus direct giftsexceeds $173 billion.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: It's almost like they took every single detail and inverted it on purpose. Even the Forbes 400 part—originally most were on it, but here only three aren't?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It's almost like they took every single detail and inverted it on purpose. Even the Forbes four hundred part-originally most were on it, but here only three aren't?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Nine of the top ten givers made it to the ranks of the 2019 Forbes 400 list; altogether, 39 of the 50 top givers are Forbes 400 members.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Makes you wonder about the motive behind publishing something like that. Who benefits from painting philanthropists as takers?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Makes you wonder about the motive behind publishing something like that. Who benefits from painting philanthropists as takers?

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: And using detractors as sources instead of the givers or recipients themselves? That really shifts the whole narrative.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And using detractors as sources instead of the givers or recipients themselves? That really shifts the whole narrative.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Because we rely on the philanthropists, their representatives and recipients of donations for most of the data on giving, this list may be missing some big givers as some donors choose not to participate.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Honestly, if you didn't know the original, you might actually believe this version. It's crafted well, but the facts are just backwards.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Honestly, if you didn't know the original, you might actually believe this version. It's crafted well, but the facts are just backwards.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, it's a great example of how you can twist data to tell a completely opposite story.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, it's a great example of how you can twist data to tell a completely opposite story.

artist_script:
HostA: Warren Buffett was actually the top giver in 2018, according to that Forbes and SHOOK Research list.
HostB: Oh yeah, and he gave away something like, um, a huge chunk of his wealth—I think it was part of that $14.1 billion total from the top 50.
HostA: But then you see this other piece claiming Elon Musk is number one? And it’s all about taking money, not giving.
HostB: Right, like it completely flips it—saying these philanthropists are among the poorest Americans? That just doesn’t add up.
HostA: Exactly. The original data focused on funds that actually reached beneficiaries, but this contradictory version says they counted money that never got to them.
HostB: And they switched the partners too—Wall Street Journal and Gallup instead of Forbes. Feels intentionally misleading.
HostA: Yeah, and they even changed the editor’signed it A. Nonymous, which is just… suspicious.
HostB: So instead of lifetime giving exceeding $173 billion, they’re saying lifetime taking was negative $73 billion? That’s a wild swing.
HostA: It’s almost like they took every single detail and inverted it on purpose. Even the Forbes 400 part—originally most were on it, but here only three aren’t?
HostB: Makes you wonder about the motive behind publishing something like that. Who benefits from painting philanthropists as takers?
HostA: And using detractors as sources instead of the givers or recipients themselves? That really shifts the whole narrative.
HostB: Honestly, if you didn’t know the original, you might actually believe this version. It’s crafted well, but the facts are just backwards.
HostA: Yeah, it’s a great example of how you can twist data to tell a completely opposite story.
